subject: Re: [junit] assertEquals(Object, Object)
msgSnippet: ... Aha! Not reflexivity, but symmetry! Now I think I understand! Was the issue that assertEquals(a,b) does not check BOTH a.equals(b) and b.equals(a)? If so,
messageBody:
> -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
>
> On Fri, 10 May 2002 21:13:21 +0300, Alexander Zynevich wrote:
>
> >it seems to me that these methods does not test transitivity
> >of equals, which is declared in Java Specification. I think
> >documentation should state that assertEquals(p1,p2) is
> >completely equiv to assertTrue(p1.equals(p2))
>
> I'm not sure, but is it possible that you mistake transitivity
> for reflexivity?

Aha! Not reflexivity, but symmetry! Now I think I understand!

Was the issue that assertEquals(a,b) does not check BOTH a.equals(b) and
b.equals(a)? If so, then again I point out that assertEquals() relies on the
correct implementation equals(); therefore, checking both properties is
redundant: if the equals() method is correctly implemented, then the a.equals
(b) <=> b.equals(a).

--
J. B. Rainsberger,
President, Diaspar Software Services
Let's write software that people understand.
